Hi everyone,
I’m not a game expert, but I wanted to share what I felt while playing Wuchang. I’ve finished the game three times in just two weeks, and honestly, I’ve completely fallen in love with it. I can’t stop thinking about Wuchang — this has become my life game.

I grew up watching Chinese action movies, so I’ve always been a fan of that style. Wuchang’s combat, story, horror atmosphere, Chinese legends, and overall world design all hit the exact things I love the most.

I also love Wukong, but Wuchang is a very different experience. I grew up with the Monkey King story since I was a child, so Wukong naturally made a big impact on me too. Now, both Wuchang and Wukong sit at the top as my favorite games of all time.

I’ve been gaming since primary school — I’m from the PS1 and PS2 generation when I was a university student. After that, I moved on to PC games like Counter-Strike. But since around 2007, I basically stopped gaming until last year.

I bought Wukong when it first came out, but it was too difficult, so I gave up after a few hours. Recently though, my rusty gaming skills improved, and when I tried Wukong again, I fell in love with it. That’s what led me to Wuchang.

At first, I wasn’t sure about Wuchang because I usually prefer hack-and-slash. But after I learned its systems — Temper, Benedictions, Jade Pendants, and Spells — and understood how to build skill sets properly, I ended up absolutely loving the gameplay. And honestly… Wuchang herself is beautiful and sexy.^^

I’ve tried other soulslike games recently, but nothing feels like Wuchang. Everything else becomes boring quickly.

I strongly recommend this game — 9.5/10.
Enjoy!

最近才有空把这个游戏给打完了，游戏一开始发售也玩过，所以前后对比还能看到制作组在难度上的变化，更多的还是削弱了 Boss 的压起身，很明显新版体验好了不少。

这游戏怎么说呢，你说它简单吧，它是魂游，一点都不简单，推图还有恶意，boss 都会长连段，不少跟 TM 疯狗一样。

但你要说它难吧，它里面有大量的轮椅，从法术到装备，到各种派生技能，很多一看就是超级轮椅，轮椅中的轮椅，而且除了那俩粪 Boss，其他的很少有快慢刀，基本上都可以用拒绝交互的方式快速击杀。讲道理找轮椅打 Boss 其实也是一种乐趣，还挺有意思的。

游戏的篝火少，地图分叉多，但是确是用心设计过的，四通发达的感觉会让你觉得很妙，但是走起来也是真的绕。

羽毛啊，体力值啊之类的元素，也是缝合了一些传统战斗ACT的长处，让游戏打起来很爽，不完全像魂系那样残疾人，但是那羽毛的 UI 就不能设计的清晰一点吗？

剧情和氛围总让我想起那个什么《卧龙苍天陨落》，碎片化叙事和到第二章为止的一些展开说实话还挺秒的，至于什么明粉，我是无法理解的，你可以不喜欢清朝，那明朝也不是啥好玩意吧，哪怕是盛唐，在历史中也是动辄杀来杀去的，不过根据我了解，玩剧情节奏的大概率也不会玩游戏，随他去吧。

游戏是个好游戏，至少是及格线以上的游戏，设计也是用了心的，甚至怕你玩不过去，给你很多轮椅。但是宣发上，细节上，还有制作人的自我表现欲上，以及那脑残的哔站KOL的合作上，踩的坑太多了，希望能给后续作品或者其他国产厂商带来告诫吧。

很多人说国产游戏崛起了崛起了，动不动销量多少多少，但在我看来，大部分人还是拿游戏当“消遣”的路人，而不是喜欢游戏本身的“玩家”，想要国单真的崛起，至少先得构建起真正的“玩家群体”和“游戏文化”，任重而道远啊。

Wuchang: Fallen Feathers is a great souls-like game, and one of the best I played. I pre-ordered and played it at launch, it had some performance and gameplay inconveniences at first, but they fixed it shortly after with a patch.
That said, I finished it before the first patch dropped and I can say that even with that, I really enjoyed it (I couldn't wait for a patch lol).
I will try to keep it organized and simple:
- Gameplay is really good and versatile, buttons are responsive, and the combat is fluid. Once you understand it, even boss fights can feel like a dance (dodges, counters, gaining skyborn might, skills, combos, magic, timing magic counter spells, fleeting, clashes, etc). No clunky movement or animations, they are well done.
- You have five weapon classes to choose from and unlock skills for, you can equip 2 weapons simultaneously, and switch freely between them in combat either regularly or with a swift draw. Every weapon class feels unique and has its advantages and disadvantages. So try the different weapons and find the ones that you like and match your play style. Each weapon category has discipline skills you can unlock from the related skill tree and equip to your weapon. Moreover, each individual weapon (even in the same class) has a unique weapon skill. You like slow hard hitting weapons? trading blows with your opponent in a quick succession with a twin blade? prefer a long reach thrusting weapon? or maybe swordplay? the game's got your back.
- Skill points can be reset at any time at no cost, and as many times as you want. You can even reset the whole skill tree and start over if you wish. The game encourages you to experiment with different stuff.
- Magic: The game has a fair amount of spells you can use; offensive, defensive and support. You can hold up to 4 spells at a time. It can help you in combat even if you are not going for a magic build. Some can help apply status effects such as burn.
- The skyborn might is a new idea, and is well implemented. You need to understand it because it is crucial for the game play, such as for certain weapon skills, moves, combos or magic.
- Difficulty: this is a souls-like game, so it is hard, BUT it is on the easier side of the games in the genre. It is quite enjoyable without being overly hard. That said, the devs made the game even easier in a later patch. Some areas became significantly easier, some enemy encounters were trivialized, some bosses were nerfed. Personally I didn't like that, it is a souls game, it is supposed to be difficult. You learn and you get better. Well, at least I finished the game once before that happened :(
- The story is average, but enjoyable. Some people complain about censorship for some story elements that was introduced in a later patch, but I played the game again after that patch and honestly it didn't really bother me. I'm not familiar with Chinese culture or historical figures, and I don't really play these games for the story.
- Level design is good, and levels are smartly interconnected. Make sure to unlock shortcuts, it will make your life easier, either for traversing the level or for backtracking, if needed, later on. Exploring is rewarding, you will often find useful items, spells, upgrade materials, etc.
- Graphics: the game is aesthetically good; models, textures, effects, magic, etc.
- Music is good, and some boss sound tracks are epic.
- Performance is not the best. It is an Unreal Engine 5 game, so it suffers from that engine's issues. However, it was improved a lot after a couple of patches.

It is a great souls-like game, worthy of your time, and a must play if you are a fan of the genre. You will enjoy it.

I really enjoyed this game. As someone who has been a fan of the Souls series for years, this scratched that familiar itch in all the right ways. If you love the interconnected world design of Dark Souls 1—with its clever shortcuts, looping pathways, and subtly mazelike structure—this game delivers that experience exceptionally well. The best comparison I can give is a blend of Dark Souls 1’s world design with the faster, more aggressive combat style of Bloodborne.

My main complaint is that I ran into some performance issues early on. During my first few hours, the audio would cut out and the game would eventually become unplayable. Fortunately, after more than 35 hours of play, these issues have only occurred a handful of times and haven’t shown up again since those initial sessions.

My only other criticism is that the late-game stretch felt a bit like a boss rush. I personally enjoy the tense, atmospheric exploration more than consecutive boss encounters. To be fair, this was partly self-inflicted, since several bosses I fought turned out to be optional depending on the ending you’re pursuing—and I didn’t realize which were which at the time.

Overall, it’s a fantastic game, and I’m already having a great time in NG+.

[h1]Good Ideas Only Get You So Far[/h1]

A lot of the chatter surrounding Wuchang has been about how familiar it feels, how it's something you've played before, something you already know whether you'll like or not, and, honestly, I find it all to be a bit disingenuous. Sure, it's unmistakably a soulslike and most of what that entails, but between its combat built around an idea wholly its own and its relatively bygone world structure, Wuchang's intentions might as well be the only thing going for it, and, well... they sort of are. Ultimately, novel design is only really as good as its execution, and developer Leenzee's debut title unfortunately comes up short almost everywhere you look.

[quote]For the full, uncut version of this review, please consider[url=https://summitreviews.biz/article/40/wuchang-fallen-feathers-review] checking it out on the Summit Reviews website.[/url][/quote]

Its narrative is the obvious place to start: you play as Wuchang, an amnesiac young warrior, as she grapples with her contraction of the Feathering, a maddening sickness indiscriminately warping its hosts into feral monstrosities—everyone but her, that is. It's an enticing opening, but just as you begin to expect an intriguing mystery that subtly hints its hand in careful visual cues and drip feeds satisfying revelations in its questlines, it so quickly devolves into an utterly rudderless mess of vague motivation, endless dialogue clarifying nothing, and, as of patch 1.5, a hoard of incongruent story alterations.

It's the structure and delivery of it all, more than anything else; there are just so many characters with so many names with so many quests that need so many items between steps that take place hours apart and they just never stop talking, each spewing out ten more names and local goings on except they all build off everyone else's exposition which works until you pick one wrong dialogue choice or take one false step without talking to a character back in some place you were at five hours ago then they just disappear forever and... are you getting all this? No? Me neither.

It's impenetrable even by soulslike standards, primarily because it neglects the genre's most potent narrative tool, substituting any meaningful attempts at environmental storytelling with yet more word vomit. There's [i]something[/i] in the almost comically archetypal military encampments literally everywhere and the trite, insipidly traditional East Asian design permeating just about everything else, but a good chunk of these places seem quite aware of their superficiality, filling the streets with bereaved citizens crying over monsters or rebels or whatever else behind closed doors, leaving the gory details to wooden voice performances and subtitles.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018684

Visual and mechanical design are two very different things, however, and, at the very least, Wuchang's world excels in the latter. Each of the four major regions are relatively isolated, but deeply connected within, flaunting ridiculously intricate, vertical spaces, more little secret side paths than you can shake a stick at, and huge areas effortlessly supported by just a single place to rest and a million one-way doors. In light of the genre more recently defaulting to a relatively linear main path supplemented by a handful of item-laden dead ends, it's a rarity to see world structure this complex, and those wonderful, crystallising moments as fragmented mental mapping suddenly falls into place are as technically impressive as they are incredibly gratifying.

There's such a thing as too much intricacy, though, and while none of these locations are ever all that confusing, they tend to feel a little manufactured. A midgame area has you climbing a series of pagoda-like structures with bizarre scaffolding and ramps between them that defy all practical sense. A later area has this impossible floating lift conveniently taking you back down to an initial resting place for seemingly no other reason than the geometry just happening to line up. And, outside of specific instances, so many ladders can be found in places no respectable human would ever defile with such a thing, and these little knee-high walls dotted around are often the only thing preventing you from skipping entire areas.

It's all just exposed seams and stitching, but it feels noticeably too authored, and that's all it really takes to transform an immersive, authentic world into a series of functional levels optimised within an inch of their life, even if those levels are otherwise pretty damn good.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018610

On the combat side, Wuchang's approach to it is fantastic. It's essentially soulslike law at this point that an attack launched after a dodge simply must be considerably weaker than anything else in your arsenal, god forbid there's any form of convenience in a genre so infamously punishing; however, Wuchang turns that entirely on its head, instead reserving some of your biggest numbers for that forbidden marriage of offence and defence. Furthermore, dodging right before an enemy attack connects grants a stack of Skyborn Might, which can then be consumed by everything from a huge range of powerful spells to the two active skills tied to any given weapon. It's fast, fluid, and, with parries still dominating the genre as though Sekiro released yesterday, placing the dodge so front and centre is really nice to see.

Or at least it should've been. In practice, each battle is defined by nothing ever feeling quite right: attacks with awkwardly long startups, animations feeling either too snappy or too sluggish, strikes not tracking properly, blows both hitting and missing when they shouldn't, and the list goes on. It's all in the game feel—little calibrations you don't pick up on until the controller's in your hands, culminating in this overwhelmingly clunky experience that's ultimately entirely antithetical to the intent. There's always some attack in your weapon's combo that grinds your momentum to a halt, and enemies are relentless, turning what should be an elegant dance into this vapid call and response, demanding nothing more than your big, flashy weapon skills over and over whenever your turn arises.

And to that end, Wuchang is painfully easy, in a way that feels quite exploitative, as well. The first nodes in each of the five weapon types' skill trees offer alternate, more efficient, and far more reliable methods of generating Skyborn Might, immediately and completely negating the whole emphasis on perfect dodges, and the moves you get to use with it are so formidable they negate almost everything else.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018574

A combination of two active skills on an early-game spear is more than capable of [i]infinitely stunlocking[/i] about half of the humanoid bosses, and just a single one of your axe skills deals massive amounts of damage and stagger, grants an ungodly amount of lifesteal, and then weaves into a basic attack that restores all the stamina and Skyborn Might you just used, culminating in this hilarious feedback loop of immortality against anything that isn't at least three times your size. Simply put, if your build makes even a modicum of sense, it's almost certainly borderline game-breaking in one way or another.

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]

Despite a lot of expectations, Wuchang: Fallen Feathers isn't just another soulslike. It iterates on things the genre should have never left behind, and its innovations are actually new and refreshing in a space widely known for how derivative it can be (it's in the name!); yet, with From Software's crown looking ever more untenable, you have to make good on your pitch. Wuchang's level design may be up to par, but between its clunky combat and nebulous, practically incomprehensible storytelling, I struggle to find anything else worth recommending.

[h1]Good Ideas Only Get You So Far[/h1]

A lot of the chatter surrounding Wuchang has been about how familiar it feels, how it's something you've played before, something you already know whether you'll like or not, and, honestly, I find it all to be a bit disingenuous. Sure, it's unmistakably a soulslike and most of what that entails, but between its combat built around an idea wholly its own and its relatively bygone world structure, Wuchang's intentions might as well be the only thing going for it, and, well... they sort of are. Ultimately, novel design is only really as good as its execution, and developer Leenzee's debut title unfortunately comes up short almost everywhere you look.

[quote]For the full, uncut version of this review, please consider[url=https://summitreviews.biz/article/40/wuchang-fallen-feathers-review] checking it out on the Summit Reviews website.[/url][/quote]

Its narrative is the obvious place to start: you play as Wuchang, an amnesiac young warrior, as she grapples with her contraction of the Feathering, a maddening sickness indiscriminately warping its hosts into feral monstrosities—everyone but her, that is. It's an enticing opening, but just as you begin to expect an intriguing mystery that subtly hints its hand in careful visual cues and drip feeds satisfying revelations in its questlines, it so quickly devolves into an utterly rudderless mess of vague motivation, endless dialogue clarifying nothing, and, as of patch 1.5, a hoard of incongruent story alterations.

It's the structure and delivery of it all, more than anything else; there are just so many characters with so many names with so many quests that need so many items between steps that take place hours apart and they just never stop talking, each spewing out ten more names and local goings on except they all build off everyone else's exposition which works until you pick one wrong dialogue choice or take one false step without talking to a character back in some place you were at five hours ago then they just disappear forever and... are you getting all this? No? Me neither.

It's impenetrable even by soulslike standards, primarily because it neglects the genre's most potent narrative tool, substituting any meaningful attempts at environmental storytelling with yet more word vomit. There's [i]something[/i] in the almost comically archetypal military encampments literally everywhere and the trite, insipidly traditional East Asian design permeating just about everything else, but a good chunk of these places seem quite aware of their superficiality, filling the streets with bereaved citizens crying over monsters or rebels or whatever else behind closed doors, leaving the gory details to wooden voice performances and subtitles.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018684

Visual and mechanical design are two very different things, however, and, at the very least, Wuchang's world excels in the latter. Each of the four major regions are relatively isolated, but deeply connected within, flaunting ridiculously intricate, vertical spaces, more little secret side paths than you can shake a stick at, and huge areas effortlessly supported by just a single place to rest and a million one-way doors. In light of the genre more recently defaulting to a relatively linear main path supplemented by a handful of item-laden dead ends, it's a rarity to see world structure this complex, and those wonderful, crystallising moments as fragmented mental mapping suddenly falls into place are as technically impressive as they are incredibly gratifying.

There's such a thing as too much intricacy, though, and while none of these locations are ever all that confusing, they tend to feel a little manufactured. A midgame area has you climbing a series of pagoda-like structures with bizarre scaffolding and ramps between them that defy all practical sense. A later area has this impossible floating lift conveniently taking you back down to an initial resting place for seemingly no other reason than the geometry just happening to line up. And, outside of specific instances, so many ladders can be found in places no respectable human would ever defile with such a thing, and these little knee-high walls dotted around are often the only thing preventing you from skipping entire areas.

It's all just exposed seams and stitching, but it feels noticeably too authored, and that's all it really takes to transform an immersive, authentic world into a series of functional levels optimised within an inch of their life, even if those levels are otherwise pretty damn good.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018610

On the combat side, Wuchang's approach to it is fantastic. It's essentially soulslike law at this point that an attack launched after a dodge simply must be considerably weaker than anything else in your arsenal, god forbid there's any form of convenience in a genre so infamously punishing; however, Wuchang turns that entirely on its head, instead reserving some of your biggest numbers for that forbidden marriage of offence and defence. Furthermore, dodging right before an enemy attack connects grants a stack of Skyborn Might, which can then be consumed by everything from a huge range of powerful spells to the two active skills tied to any given weapon. It's fast, fluid, and, with parries still dominating the genre as though Sekiro released yesterday, placing the dodge so front and centre is really nice to see.

Or at least it should've been. In practice, each battle is defined by nothing ever feeling quite right: attacks with awkwardly long startups, animations feeling either too snappy or too sluggish, strikes not tracking properly, blows both hitting and missing when they shouldn't, and the list goes on. It's all in the game feel—little calibrations you don't pick up on until the controller's in your hands, culminating in this overwhelmingly clunky experience that's ultimately entirely antithetical to the intent. There's always some attack in your weapon's combo that grinds your momentum to a halt, and enemies are relentless, turning what should be an elegant dance into this vapid call and response, demanding nothing more than your big, flashy weapon skills over and over whenever your turn arises.

And to that end, Wuchang is painfully easy, in a way that feels quite exploitative, as well. The first nodes in each of the five weapon types' skill trees offer alternate, more efficient, and far more reliable methods of generating Skyborn Might, immediately and completely negating the whole emphasis on perfect dodges, and the moves you get to use with it are so formidable they negate almost everything else.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3590018574

A combination of two active skills on an early-game spear is more than capable of [i]infinitely stunlocking[/i] about half of the humanoid bosses, and just a single one of your axe skills deals massive amounts of damage and stagger, grants an ungodly amount of lifesteal, and then weaves into a basic attack that restores all the stamina and Skyborn Might you just used, culminating in this hilarious feedback loop of immortality against anything that isn't at least three times your size. Simply put, if your build makes even a modicum of sense, it's almost certainly borderline game-breaking in one way or another.

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]

Despite a lot of expectations, Wuchang: Fallen Feathers isn't just another soulslike. It iterates on things the genre should have never left behind, and its innovations are actually new and refreshing in a space widely known for how derivative it can be (it's in the name!); yet, with From Software's crown looking ever more untenable, you have to make good on your pitch. Wuchang's level design may be up to par, but between its clunky combat and nebulous, practically incomprehensible storytelling, I struggle to find anything else worth recommending.

They had a pretty good chance to be a nice game people would remember positively, but they failed in the end.

Positives: excellent optimization and graphics, nice visuals here and there, a pretty okay builds system that allows you to change your playstyle (in reality adapting to the required by current boss build set). BTW, still here they followed this recent trend of naming things unique ways. Meaning when you try to understand what this or that skill does, you will literally read encyclopedia of their unique terms for usual words like "invincibility window" or other usual ones, before you learn them and start to understand better what they mean. Sometimes my eyes were bleeding of these terms, like you were translating some new language, you know.
I think this is where the positives end.

The game suffers from pretty childish issues that start instantly when you open the game. Controls - who hasn't mentioned them yet? Assigning a run button to the A button on Xbox controller is something I have not seen in any game. It looks like developers never played a game on a gamepad and don't understand that you still need you right stick to look around while running and you can't do that holding the A. Much later they introduced re-assigning the buttons which I used but it was also done in a very lame way so that when I swapped A with another button (weapon special in my case) - the button approving dialogues/interacting or picking up things still remained A. And it means every time you slightly missed the item or held the skip cinematic for too long you will trigger a long animation of a strike or whatever you reassigned it with. I'm not sure if any of them devs played it after they made the changes.
The "madness descends" notification  that you for some reason see every time blocks any interaction and adds around 5 seconds of waiting before you can re-try the boss.
They show you cinematic before the boss every time, so you could skip it. I thought it was 2025.

The general difficulty of the game did not seem too high for me, I beat most of the bosses (except some of the first ones) without assistance. Still fights are somehow staged. You really need to dance up to the devs plan and dodge-dodge-dodge-dodge-dodge then maybe you can hit. Those who say this game can be treated as a non-parry one lie, there is no practical difference, just a different move. Yep, some magics really make it easier, but you still need to dodge all the way through. This lack of variety in the battle approach is kind of lacking.
They were also crazy about the labyrinths and forks in the roads and decided to do almost each level like this which at times was very annoying, but this is still manageable in the end.

And the last but not the least thing. They say a lot that this game is so punishing etc. I don't think it is so much of a punishing game, all is pretty much standard, though it seems the devs did not have enough creativity of how to make it hard so there's so many sudden "you died" moments including the stupid uninterruptable moves of some bosses. In my opinion they simply elongated the game in this way, but was it so hard? I don't think so. But what will actually punish you or I'd say it correctly frustrate you is the stupidity of the story line. YOU HAVE TO progress in the game according to the devs plan and if you step aside a little (and they well allow you to do that) - you will ruin the questline and will not get a proper ending. And it is so easy to do so, just read the internets! Quests never been a strong side of the souls games, but none of the one I played had this for the major questlnes, side ones - yes, but not the main ones. They literally give you the opportunity to kill bosses in a WRONG ORDER (WHAT?) and bang you've missed it. I've read some comments from china players like "hey, that's clear as a day in the dialogues" - well no, it is not and thousands of complaining players are the proof to that. You did not adapt your dialogues for the international market and play the game in chinese language and know the legends etc. For the rest of the world most of the dialogue lines are meaningless and don't add up. This is a  total game design flaw and it seems that people creating this thought that later after the first fail you will want to replay in a correct order on an NG+. No way, people, I'll not open this game again after such approaches and issues described before. 
You still have a ton to learn from Japanese developers unfortunately, though you have already gone a long way, I admit.
